case_name: Badri Prasad v. State of Madhya Pradesh

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 672 of 1964 arises from judgment and decree dated October 1962 of Madhya Pradesh High Court in First Appeal No. 8 of 1960.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 672 of 1964. Appeal by special leave from the judgement and decree dated October 1962 of the Madhya Pradesh High Court in First Appeal No. 8 of 1960.

facts.text: Appellant instituted suit for declaration that he was not liable to pay amount originally due from defendant-respondent No. 2 and for permanent injunction restraining State Government from recovering the amount.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal, by special leave, arises out of a suit instituted by the appellant for a declaration that he was number liable to pay a certain amount originally due from defendant-respondent No. 2 and for the issue of a permanent injunction restraining the State Government, Madhya Pradesh, defendant respondent No. 1 from companytinuing the proceedings for the recovery of the amount or for starting any fresh proceedings.

facts.text: Trial Court decreed the suit in favor of appellant but High Court reversed the decree and dismissed the suit.

anchor.surface_text: The suit was decreed by the Trial Court but, on appeal, the High Court reversed the decree and dismissed the appellants suit.

facts.text: On December 24, 1956, respondent No. 2 purchased at public auction by Divisional Forest Officer, Harda, cut timber and arkat trees of Coupe No. 9 Eastern, East Kalibhit Range, Harda Forest Division, for Rs. 70,200.

anchor.surface_text: The admitted facts of the case are that on December 24, 1956, respondent No. 2 purchased at the public auction sale held by the Divisional Forest Officer, Harda, the cut timber and arkat trees of companype No. 9 Eastern, East Kalibhit Range, in Harda Forest Division, for Rs. 70,200.

facts.text: Appellant stood surety for respondent No. 2, the purchaser.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant stood surety for the purchaser, viz., respondent No. 2.

facts.text: Purchase price to be paid in four instalments: Rs. 17,600 at once (paid), others due March 1, May 15, December 15, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: The purchase price was to be paid in four instalments, according to para 4 of the deed of companytract. Rs. 17,600 were to be paid at once and were so paid. The other instalments were due on March 1, May 15 and December 15, 1957.

facts.text: Respondent No. 2 did not pay the other instalments, so respondent No. 1 proceeded against appellant for recovery.

anchor.surface_text: These instalments were number paid by respondent No. 2 and hence respondent No. 1 took proceedings against the appellant for the recovery of the amount.

facts.text: Boundary certificate Exhibit D-1 furnished on February 5, 1957; appellant signed as witness.

anchor.surface_text: This certificate, Exhibit D-1, was furnished on February 5, 1957 and stated that the respondent No. 2 had clearly understood the boundaries of the areas companyered by the lease and that he had taken possession of the standing felled companylected material in the aforesaid companype as announced at the auction and described in the said lease and that he was satisfied that the quantity delivered to him agreed substantially with that announced at the auction. The appellant Badri Prasad signed this certificate as a witness.

facts.text: Work to continue up to June 30, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: The work companyld companytinue upto June 30, 1958.

facts.text: Formal deed of contract signed by Chief Conservator of Forests on May 3, 1957; preamble gives date May 3, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: The formal deed of companytract was signed by the Chief Conser- vator of Forests on May 3, 1957 and the preamble of the deed gives the date of the making of the companytract to be May 3, 1957.

facts.text: First Schedule signed by contractor and Divisional Forest Officer on December 24, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: This is signed by the companytractor, respondent No. 2 and by the Divisional Forest Officer, Harda Division, dated December 24, 1956.

facts.text: Security bond signed by appellant on December 29, 1956, by Divisional Forest Officer on March 30, 1957, countersigned by Chief Conservator on May 3, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: The security bond was signed by the appellant on December 29, 1956 and by the Divisional Forest Officer on March 30, 1957 and was companyntersigned by the Chief Conservator on May 3, 1957.

facts.text: Coupe divided into four sections A, B, C, D per r. 18 of Forest Contract Rules.

anchor.surface_text: The entire companype whose cut timber was sold to the respondent was divided into four sections A, B, C and D. This was done in accordance with r. 18 of the Forest Contract Rules.

facts.text: Respondent No. 2 began operations in section A in the last week of February 1957.

anchor.surface_text: Respondent No. 2, the companytractor, began his operations in section A of the companype in the last week of February, 1957.

facts.text: Respondent No. 2 defaulted on second instalment due March 1, 1957, did not pay till April 25, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: He defaulted in the payment of the second instalment which was due on March 1, 1957 and did number pay that amount till April 25, 1957, though it was demanded several times from him.

facts.text: Notice Exhibit P4 issued to respondent No. 2 on March 23, 1957 regarding excess removal over deposit.

anchor.surface_text: On March 23, 1957 a numberice. Exhibit P4, was issued to him. It stated You are being informed through this numberice that the removal of goods from the companype by you is already in excess of the amount deposited by you in the treasury.

facts.text: On April 25, 1957, appellant informed no further removal allowed due to default; licence book and transit pass taken back.

anchor.surface_text: On April 25, 1957 the appellant was told by the forest authorities that numberfurther removal of the forest produce would be allowed in view of the default of payment of the second instalment. The licence book and the transit pass were taken back by the Government Forester, Madanlal Pagare.

facts.text: Fire broke out in the forest; cut timber sold to respondent No. 2 was burnt. Report Exhibit D2 dated April 29, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: Fire broke out in the forest and the cut timber sold to res- pondent No. 2 was burnt. The report about the loss from fire is Exhibit D2 dated April 29, 1957 and is signed by the companytractor and Sheoprasad Parashar. the Forest Guard.

facts.text: As a result of fire, goods purchased by respondent No. 2 and not removed ceased to exist.

anchor.surface_text: As a result of the fire the goods purchased by respondent No. 2 and number removed by then, ceased to exist.

facts.text: Respondent No. 2 did not pay 2nd, 3rd, 4th instalments.

anchor.surface_text: He did number pay the amounts due for the 2nd, 3rd and 4th instalments.

facts.text: Appellant claimed not put in possession of timber in sections B, C, D, no transfer of property.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant sought to avoid his liability as surety for the number-payment of the amount inter-alia on the -round that the companytractor respondent No. 2 had number been put in possession of the cut timber sold to him except of such timber which had been in section A of companype No. 9, that therefore there had been numbertransfer of property in the timber sold to him

facts.text: In plaint para 5A, appellant averred possession of each section delivered on payment of each instalment.

anchor.surface_text: It was averred by the appellant in paragraph 5 A  of the plaint Thus it was clearly understood on both sides and also explained by the Forest Department officials of defendant No. 1 and which has been all along implicit in the companytract as per usual practices of the forest department that the possession of the goods of each respective section will be delivered to the Contractor on payment of each instalment as stated above.

facts.text: Respondent No. 1 admitted paras 5B and 5C of plaint regarding hammer marking, checks, etc.

anchor.surface_text: Respondent No. 1 admitted what was stated in paras 5 B   C  of the plaint. It denied the understanding as averred in para 5 A

facts.text: Fire broke out in last week of April 1957.

anchor.surface_text: the property in the cut timber sold and existing in sections B, C and D of the companype had number passed to the companytractor before the fire broke out in the last week of April 1957

facts.text: Trace of coupe sold signed by respondent No. 2 and DFO on November 29, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: The trace of the companype sold was signed by respondent No. 2 and the Divisional Forest Officer on November 29, 1956, prior to the actual auction sale.
Appeal by special leave from the judgement and decree dated October 1962

issues.text: Whether the property in the cut timber sold and existing in sections B, C and D of the coupe had passed to the contractor before the fire broke out in the last week of April 1957?

anchor.surface_text: The main question urged before us is that the property in the cut timber sold and existing in sections B, C and D of the coupe had not passed to the contractor before the fire broke out in the last week of April 1957 and this contention is based on the facts that the goods sold were not specific goods as they had not been hammer-marked, that the goods in sections B, C and D could not be delivered till the 2nd, 3rd and 4th instalments had been paid and that the deed of contract was signed after the fire had taken place.

issues.text: Whether the goods sold were specific goods given the lack of certain hammer marks?

anchor.surface_text: The omission to put such marks does not make the goods sold unascertained. The felled trees sold to the respondent No. 2 had a butt mark at the butt end.

issues.text: Whether delivery/possession of timber in sections B, C and D was conditioned on payment of subsequent instalments per the alleged understanding?

anchor.surface_text: Thus it was clearly understood on both sides and also explained by the Forest Department officials of defendant No. 1 and which has been all along implicit in the contract as per usual practices of the forest department that the possession of the goods of each respective section will be delivered to the Contractor on payment of each instalment as stated above.

issues.text: Whether the deed of contract signed by the Chief Conservator after the fire affected the passing of property or the date of the contract?

anchor.surface_text: His formal signature on the deed of contract relates back the contract to the date of auction when the bid of respondent No. 2 was provisionally accepted

issues.text: Whether r. 8 of the Forest Contract Rules reserved a right of disposal by the seller such that s. 25(1) of the Sale of Goods Act applied and property did not pass?

anchor.surface_text: therefore s. 25(1) of the Indian Sale of Goods Act, 1930 Act III of 1930 applies to the facts of the case and that therefore, notwithstanding, delivery of the forest produce

issues.text: Whether the contract could be executed or ratified by the Chief Conservator after the fire destroyed the goods in sections B, C and D?

holdings.text: The felled trees sold to respondent No. 2 were specific goods as they had a butt mark at the butt end and presumption of compliance with felling rules applies.

anchor.surface_text: The omission to put such marks does not make the goods sold unascertained. The felled trees sold to the respondent No. 2 had a butt mark at the butt end. A similar hammer mark existed on the stem near which the felled tree must have lain, it being presumed that the rules for the felling of trees were properly complied with by the forest authorities, mentioned above. The goods sold therefore were specified goods.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Omission of further hammer marks does not render goods unascertained; butt marks suffice and felling rules presumed followed.

holdings.text: There is no condition in the contract or r.18 Forest Contract Rules requiring delivery of possession of sections B, C, D only after payment of subsequent instalments.

anchor.surface_text: There is nothing in the contract that possession would not be delivered over the cut timber in sections B, C and D till the 2nd, 3rd and 4th instalments have been paid. The relevant provisions of r. 18 of the Forest Contract Rules, extracted earlier, do not contain any such restriction. It only provides that the operations necessary to be conducted by the contractor had to start with section A or the first section and that the rights of the contractor to the material purchased would be deemed to be surrendered in certain circumstances.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Contract and r.18 regulate operations sequentially but do not link possession or delivery to instalment payments; alleged understanding denied by respondent.

holdings.text: The Chief Conservator's signature on the deed of contract relates back to the date of the auction sale.

anchor.surface_text: His formal signature on the deed of contract relates back the contract to the date of auction when the bid of respondent No. 2 was provisionally accepted and he and the Divisional Forest Officer signed the contract.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Provisional acceptance at auction; formalities nearly complete; executive instructions contemplate delayed signature without affecting sale date.

holdings.text: Property in the cut timber in sections B, C and D passed to the contractor before the fire under s.20 Sale of Goods Act.

anchor.surface_text: it is s. 20 of the Sale of Goods Act which will apply to this case. This section provides that where there is an unconditional contract for the sale of specific goods in a deliverable state, the property in the goods passes to the buyer when the contract is made and it is immaterial whether the time of payment of price or the time of delivery of the goods or both is postponed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Unconditional contract for specific goods in deliverable state; property passes on contract formation irrespective of payment/delivery timing; instalments deemed full payment at delivery per rules.

holdings.text: r.8 Forest Contract Rules does not reserve seller's right of disposal under s.25(1) Sale of Goods Act; it enforces statutory lien under s.83 Indian Forest Act.

anchor.surface_text: therefore s. 25(1) of the Indian Sale of Goods Act, 1930 (Act III of 1930) applies to the facts of the case... There is nothing in the deed of contract or in the Forest Contract Rules which reserved such a right of disposal in the State. Right given to the Government under r. 8 is the right to stop the removal of forest produce when the value of the forest produce already removed exceeded the amount of the instalments paid.

holdings.reasoning_summary: r.8 regulates compliance and enforces first charge/lien on produce for unpaid amounts, not contractual reservation of disposal right.

holdings.text: Execution of contract by Chief Conservator after fire valid; ratification possible post-loss as contract contemplates such risks per r.32 Forest Contract Rules.
holdings.reasoning_summary: No prejudice to third parties; precedents allow post-loss ratification where risk contemplated; r.32 denies compensation for fire loss, supporting liability.

holdings.text: Divisional Forest Officer acted within authority at auction; no unauthorized act requiring ratification, merely formal completion of deed.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes High Court's ratification view; auction and provisional acceptance authorized; signature completes execution relating back.

holdings.text: Appellant's suit rightly dismissed; surety liable for unpaid instalments.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that the appellants suit has been rightly dismissed by the High Court. We accordingly dismiss the appeal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: All contentions rejected; property passed pre-fire, no defenses to liability under contract and surety bond.

precedents.citation: Williams v. North China Insurance Co. 1 L.R. 1876 1 C.P.D. 757

anchor.surface_text: In Williams v. North China Insurance Co. 1  this proposition was sought to be reviewed. Cockburn C.J. said at p. 764 The existing authorities certainly show that when an insurance is effected without authority by one person on anothers behalf, the principal may ratify the insurance even after the loss is known. Mr. Benjamin asked us, as a Court of Appeal, to review those authorities Where an agent effected an insurance subject to ratification, the loss insured against is very likely to happen before ratification, and it must be taken that the insurance so effected involves that possibility as the basis of the companytract.

precedents.case_name: Williams v. North China Insurance Co.
precedents.cited_proposition: Ratification by principal of insurance effected without authority can occur even after knowledge of loss, as the contract contemplates the possibility of loss before ratification.
precedents.cited_holding: The existing authorities certainly show that when an insurance is effected without authority by one person on anothers behalf, the principal may ratify the insurance even after the loss is known.

justification_sets.label: Sale of Goods Act s.20 support

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that the appellants suit has been rightly dismissed by the High Court. We accordingly dismiss the appeal.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal dismissed; High Court's dismissal of the suit upheld; appellant (surety) held liable.

edges.explanation: Holding h1 that trees were specific goods with butt mark addresses issue i2 on whether goods were specific given lack of hammer marks

anchor.surface_text: The omission to put such marks does not make the goods sold unascertained. The felled trees sold to the respondent No. 2 had a butt mark at the butt end. A similar hammer mark existed on the stem near which the felled tree must have lain, it being presumed that the rules for the felling of trees were properly complied with by the forest authorities, mentioned above. The goods sold therefore were specified goods.
We are therefore of opinion that the appellants suit has been rightly dismissed by the High Court. We accordingly dismiss the appeal.

edges.explanation: Holding resolves the issue by confirming no condition in r.18 Forest Contract Rules.

anchor.surface_text: There is nothing in the contract that possession would not be delivered over the cut timber in sections B, C and D till the 2nd, 3rd and 4th instalments have been paid. The relevant provisions of r. 18 of the Forest Contract Rules, extracted earlier, do not contain any such restriction. It only provides that the operations necessary to be conducted by the contractor had to start with section A or the first section and that the rights of the contractor to the material purchased would be deemed to be surrendered in certain circumstances.
We are therefore of opinion that the appellants suit has been rightly dismissed by the High Court. We accordingly dismiss the appeal.

anchor.surface_text: His formal signature on the deed of contract relates back the contract to the date of auction when the bid of respondent No. 2 was provisionally accepted and he and the Divisional Forest Officer signed the contract.
We are therefore of opinion that the appellants suit has been rightly dismissed by the High Court. We accordingly dismiss the appeal.

edges.explanation: Holding h4 that property passed before fire under s.20 addresses issue i1

anchor.surface_text: it is s. 20 of the Sale of Goods Act which will apply to this case. This section provides that where there is an unconditional contract for the sale of specific goods in a deliverable state, the property in the goods passes to the buyer when the contract is made and it is immaterial whether the time of payment of price or the time of delivery of the goods or both is postponed.
We are therefore of opinion that the appellants suit has been rightly dismissed by the High Court. We accordingly dismiss the appeal.

anchor.surface_text: therefore s. 25(1) of the Indian Sale of Goods Act, 1930 (Act III of 1930) applies to the facts of the case... There is nothing in the deed of contract or in the Forest Contract Rules which reserved such a right of disposal in the State. Right given to the Government under r. 8 is the right to stop the removal of forest produce when the value of the forest produce already removed exceeded the amount of the instalments paid.
We are therefore of opinion that the appellants suit has been rightly dismissed by the High Court. We accordingly dismiss the appeal.
